title: What is LANDFIRE
text:
LANDFIRE, Landscape Fire and Resource Management Planning Tools, is a shared program between the wildland fire management programs of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service Fire and Aviation branch, and the U.S. Department of the Interior, that provides more than twenty landscape-scale geo-spatial products, 950 vegetation models, and a suite of tools that support all-lands planning, management, and operations. Learn more about the dynamic LANDFIRE Program.


LANDFIRE‚Äôs mission is to provide agency leaders and managers with a common ‚Äúall-lands‚Äù data set of vegetation and wildland fire/fuels information for strategic fire and resource management planning and analysis.



The LANDFIRE Program delivers current, consistent, comprehensive data for the entire United States, including Alaska, Hawai‚Äôi, and Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands.
This multi-partner program produces current, consistent, comprehensive, geospatial data and databases that describe vegetation, wildland fuel, and fire regimes across the United States and insular areas. Use the LANDFIRE Technical Documentation to learn how LF creates the data. Use the LANDFIRE Data Dictionary to help understand and locate LANDFIRE information.
LF products are available by the following groupings:

Reference - contribute data or access databases containing contributed disturbance events
Disturbance - a suite of products that categorizes annual and historical disturbance events
Vegetation - products that demonstrate vegetation change across the landscape and models of potential pre-European settlement vegetation systems
Fuel - products that demonstrate the composition and characteristics of surface and canopy fuels along with fuel vegetation
Historical Fire Regime - products that represent pre-European settlement fire frequency and severity
Topographic - products that provide geospatial information describing the landscape

title: What is LANDFIRE
section: What is The Nature Conservancy‚Äôs connection?
text:
What is The Nature Conservancy‚Äôs connection?
The Nature Conservancy (TNC) is a major partner in the LANDFIRE Program supported by a cooperative agreement through the USDA Forest Service. TNC‚Äôs LANDFIRE Team works closely with the LANDFIRE Business Leads, program staff, and other partners to provide support to LANDFIRE users.
LANDFIRE user support can take many forms. Providing this assistance can range from in-person and online workshops to monthly office hours, newsletters and data alerts to learning website development and technical, personalized assistance. TNC‚Äôs LANDFIRE team is dedicated to developing current, user-focused LANDFIRE resources that advance natural resource work, amplify the appropriate use of LANDFIRE products, and leverage the collective knowledge of the natural resource community.
LANDFIRE‚Äôs website offers a wealth of resources related to wildland fire and natural resource management. Users can access all LANDFIRE data, resources, applications, and update information on the LANDFIRE Program website.

title: Biophysical Settings Descriptions
text: The Biophysical Settings (BpS) Descriptions are a foundational LANDFIRE product. They set the stage for development of many other LANDFIRE products such as the Biophysical Settings and Succession Class spatial datasets.

title: Biophysical Settings Descriptions
text:
To download all BpS descriptions
üí° Screenshots are provided below for those who want them.

Navigate to the Biophysical Settings Models and Descriptions page of the LANDFIRE Program website (Vegetation‚Üí Biophysical Settings Models and Descriptions).
Scroll down to the Download BpS Models and Descriptions Section near the bottom of the page.
Here you will see two options: ‚ÄúRevised CONUS and Hawaii‚Äù models and ‚ÄúOriginal Alaska‚Äù models. Select whichever set you would like, then click on the ‚ÄúBpS Descriptions‚Äù which will trigger downloading of a .zip file named ‚ÄúLANDFIRE_CONUS-HI_BpS_Descriptions_Jan2023.zip‚Äù (for Revised CONUS and Hawaii) that has 819 Word documents or ‚ÄúAlaska_Original_BpS_Descriptions.zip‚Äù (for Alaska) that has 12 pdf documents. This file will most likely land in your ‚ÄúDownloads‚Äù directory.
Use your extraction tool of choice to unzip and explore. One possible way if you are using Windows is to:

right click the file
select ‚ÄòExtract all‚Äô to access the Windows extraction tool.

Go to the search page.
From here, there are multiple ways to select BpS documents to download:

Use the filters on the left side of the page:

Use the checkboxes under the ‚ÄúMap Zone‚Äù heading to select all BpS documents for one or more LANDFIRE Map Zones (#2 on ‚ÄòWays to select‚Äô screenshot below).

Search for a BpS of interest by typing in the ‚ÄòSearch‚Ä¶‚Äô box (#3 on ‚ÄòWays to select‚Äô screenshot below). A few things to keep in mind when searching:

You can search by genus and/or species or common name (e.g., ‚ÄòFraxinus‚Äô, or ‚ÄòWhite Ash‚Äô )
Most text terms will work, numbers will not. For example, ‚Äòhurricane‚Äô will return BpSs, ‚Äò1362‚Äô (an actual BpS number) will not.
You can first filter by ‚ÄòVegetation Types‚Äô and/or ‚ÄòMap Zones‚Äô, then search to narrow results.

title: Biophysical Settings Descriptions
section: File name, Map Zones and that number at the top
text:
File name, Map Zones and that number at the top
The BpS documents were saved with a numeric code such as ‚Äú13700_60_63_64_65_66.docx‚Äù. This number represents three things:

BpS code: this is the first 4 digits, e.g., ‚Äú1370‚Äù in our example for the ‚ÄúAppalachian (Hemlock-)Northern Hardwood Forest‚Äù.
BpS splits: this is the fifth digit, or ‚Äú0‚Äù in our example. Occasionally an original BpS would be ‚Äòsplit‚Äô into multiple. For example, in the Great Lakes there is a ‚ÄúBoreal White Spruce-Fir-Hardwood Forest - Inland‚Äù (BpS code 13651), and a ‚ÄúBoreal White Spruce-Fir-Hardwood Forest - Coastal‚Äù (BpS code 13652), which have a ‚Äú1‚Äù and a ‚Äú2‚Äù in the file name, and BpS code.
Map Zones: the string of numbers separated by an underscore represents the Map Zones that this particular document (and associated BpS state and transition model) apply to.







üí° Why are Map Zones important?
Map zones in LANDFIRE are created through a collaborative effort involving multiple organizations including USGS, US DOI, USDA Forest Service and TNC. Map zones are important for LANDFIRE because they divide the landscape into manageable sections, ensuring consistent data collection and analysis including modeling vegetation and fire and fuels behavior. Each map zone represents distinct ecological regions, helping to depict reference conditions and natural plant communities that existed historically.

title: Biophysical Settings Descriptions
text:
Fire Frequency Table
The Fire Frequency Table can be confusing. A few things to keep in mind when viewing this table include:

The Severity, Avg FI (FI - Fire Interval), and Percent of All Fires values are imported from the Syncro Sim model
The values in the Avg FI and Percent of All Fires columns are essentially a ‚Äòcomposite‚Äô across all succession classes, which may include classes which have very short FIs, and classes with very long FIs.
The Min FI and Max FI columns are user populated, and may not necessarily correspond to the Avg FI and Percent of All Fires columns.

An example Fire Frequency table is replicated below.

Fire interval is expressed in years for each fire severity class and for all types of fire combined (All Fires). Average FI is the central tendency modeled. Percent of all fires is the percent of fires modeled in that severity class. Minimum and Maximum FIs show the relative range of fire intervals as estimated by model contributors, if known.

title: Biophysical Settings Descriptions
text:
Succession Classes Table
LANDFIRE did not attempt to map where succession classes were prior to European colonization, as they would have moved around. This table is used to map where succession classes are today. For example, in the ‚ÄòSuccession Class Table‚Äô below we have highlighted combinations of Existing Height and Cover (and lifeform) that would be mapped as Succession Class A.

Model Parameters Table
This table is essentially an ‚Äòexport‚Äô of the SyncroSim model parameters. In other words, experts entered in all of the natural disturbances they knew about into the modeling software, and this table has all of those disturbances, numbers and the ‚Äòresults‚Äô of those disturbances.
In the ‚ÄòModel Parameters Table‚Äô below the top row that would read something like ‚Äúthe wind/weather/stress disturbance would impact the Early1:All succession class once every 1000 years on average (or 0.1% of the succession class yearly on average), and when that disturbance happened, the vegetation would respond by returning back to the beginning of the Early1: All succession class.‚Äù

title: Biophysical Settings: An Overview
text:
Biophysical Settings are a foundational concept for LANDFIRE defined on the LANDFIRE Program website as:

‚Äú‚Ä¶a modeled representation of the vegetation system that may have been dominant on the landscape prior to Euro-American settlement and is based on both the current biophysical environment and an approximation of modeled past disturbance regimes.‚Äù

We like to think of the BpSs as ‚Äúecosystem habitats‚Äù, or ‚Äúpotential ecosystem footprints‚Äù. The BpS concept asks ‚Äúwhere might an ecosystem occur‚Äù based on abiotic factors such as soils, surficial geology, slope and elevation as well as natural disturbance regimes.

title: LANDFIRE 101
text:
Imagine you are Rhonda (District) Ranger. On your district are many land management challenges and opportunities including timber harvest, wildfire, fuels buildup, recreation, wildlife habitat alteration and climate change. Many of the broad goals and objectives are written in the forest plan, but you have flexibility at the project level and must decide what to do when. This is no easy task as there may be competing interests. Information alone will not solve the problem, but is necessary for documentation, trust building, and informed decision making. While LANDFIRE does not provide every single dataset, tool or model for every natural resource decision, the products typically provide a solid starting point.
Welcome to LANDFIRE 101, an introduction to the essential elements of LANDFIRE - Landscape Fire and Resource Management Planning tools - a crucial resource for land management and conservation. This platform is designed to familiarize you with the LANDFIRE Program, its comprehensive website (landfire.gov), and some of the invaluable datasets it provides.
This LANDFIRE 101 learning website serves as a supporting addendum to the comprehensive LANDFIRE Program website. The LANDFIRE 101 learning website can be followed from start-to-finish and provides practical support for new LANDFIRE users. This supporting site should be used in conjunction to (not instead of) the LANDFIRE Program website. As such, we provide essentials for getting started with using and applying LANDFIRE products and each page provides multiple opportunities for exploring these data further on the comprehensive LANDFIRE Program website.
Whether you are a novice or seeking to deepen your expertise, this training platform provides the insights and practical skills necessary for leveraging LANDFIRE data in your projects. We invite you to join us and discover how these powerful tools can support your endeavors in land management and beyond.


Our LANDFIRE 101 learning website provides a foundation for:

Understanding each LANDFIRE vegetation product and selected fuels products
Navigating the LANDFIRE Program website to find and download LANDFIRE products
Explaining important attributes of LANDFIRE vegetation and fuels products
Learning about LANDFIRE use cases
Avoiding common misapplications of the data, knowledge of frequently encountered issues, and overcoming potential data pitfalls

title: Biophysical Settings Spatial Data
text:
An overview of the Biophysical Settings spatial data
Key attributes of the Biophysical Settings spatial data
Where to find Biophysical Settings data on the LANDFIRE Program website
Common mistakes with Biophysical Settings data (and how to avoid them)









LANDFIRE delivers Biophysical Settings data and models for the entire United States, including Alaska and Hawaii. Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands do not have BpS data developed. 950 Biophysical Settings are grouped into seven major vegetation classes and displayed using one color family for each class.





LANDFIRE‚Äôs Biophysical Settings spatial product, also known as BpS, is a spatial representation of the BpS concept we discussed in the previous section. LANDFIRE uses BpS to depict reference conditions of vegetation across landscapes.
As of 2016, BpS now includes information on the historical fire regime, such as fire return intervals, percent of fire severities, and fire regime groups. Since LANDFIRE‚Äôs fire regime information is based on the historic context, we include it with BpS to provide a better picture of the pre-colonization landscape to the best of our knowledge.
The Biophysical Settings attributes correspond with the information in the Biophysical Settings Descriptions discussed in the BpS Descriptionsection of this website. We suggest that you review this information for a more complete understanding of the Biophysical Settings attributes.
For even more information, we‚Äôve created this short BpS 101 video on YouTube (3 minutes ).




BPS_CODE: The unique code LANDFIRE uses for each Biophysical Setting
Zone: The NLCD map zone(s) the Bps is located in or relates to
BPS_MODEL: The unique BpS Model code. This combines the BpS code with the zone(s) the model is located in. In some cases, a BpS with the same name and BpS Code may be split among map zones because the vegetation or disturbance regimes vary enough that the descriptions differ. An example of this is the ‚ÄòLaurentian-Acadian Northern Hardwoods forest‚Äô BpS (13020), which has four different BpS Models, although it is mapped as one BpS type.
BPS_NAME: The name of the Biophysical Setting. The name is matched to the BpS Code, not the BpS model number.
GROUPVEG: Coarse vegetation type groupings highlighting the high-level dominant vegetation within that BpS. Note that if a BpS is listed as ‚ÄòHardwood‚Äô it may actually be a mix of hardwood, herbaceous, savannah, and more, but LANDFIRE‚Äôs mapping identified hardwoods as dominating most of the landscape.
Fire Regime Attributes

FRI_REPLAC: Average historic replacement-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_MIXED: Average historic mixed-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_SURFAC: Average historic surface-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_ALLFIR: Average historic fire frequency for all fires within the BpS.
PRC_REPLAC: Percent of historic fires with replacement severity for the BpS
PRC_MIXED: Percent of historic fires with mixed serverity for the BpS
PRC_SURFAC: Percent of historic fires with surface severity for the BpS
FRG_NEW: The fire regime group this BpS is found in. Fire regime groups are based on a combination of fire return interval and fire severity. The current Fire Regime Groups were updated in 2016, and have been modified from a previous classification. You can find the new breakdown of fire regime groups in the Attribute Data Dictionaryfor the BpS spatial data.





The Biophysical Settings data is included in the Vegetation section of the LANDFIRE Program Website on the Biophysical Settings page. Here you will find an overview, including the information above along with further details and links to other important documents. Perhaps of most interest are the download links - via the LANDFIRE Map Viewer, full extent downloads, and a variety of ways to stream data into your maps. The page also includes resources such as attribute tables, metadata, and supplemental information.



Screenshot of Data Access and Resources on the Biophysical Settings data page






Bps Attribute Data Dictionary
LANDFIRE Helpdesk

title: Biophysical Settings Spatial Data
text:
LANDFIRE‚Äôs Biophysical Settings data, also known as BpS, represents the vegetation system that may have been dominant on the landscape prior to European colonization and is based on both the current biophysical environment and an approximation of the historical disturbance regime. LANDFIRE uses BpS to depict reference conditions of vegetation across landscapes.
As of 2016, BpS now includes information on the historical fire regime, such as fire return intervals, percent of fire severities, and fire regime groups. Since LANDFIRE‚Äôs fire regime information is based on the historic context, we include it with BpS to provide a better picture of the pre-colonization landscape to the best of our knowledge.
The Biophysical Settings attributes correspond with the information in the Biophysical Settings Descriptions discussed in the BpS Description section of this website. We suggest that you review this information for a more complete understanding of the Biophysical Settings attributes.
For even more information, we‚Äôve created this short BpS 101 video on YouTube (3 minutes ).



BPS_CODE: The unique code LANDFIRE uses for each Biophysical Setting
Zone: The NLCD map zone(s) the Bps is located in or relates to
BPS_MODEL: The unique BpS Model code. This combines the BpS code with the zone(s) the model is located in. In some cases, a BpS with the same name and BpS Code may be split among map zones because the vegetation or disturbance regimes vary enough that the descriptions differ. An example of this is the ‚ÄòLaurentian-Acadian Northern Hardwoods forest‚Äô BpS (13020), which has four different BpS Models, although it is mapped as one BpS type. (See the screenshot below.)
BPS_NAME: The name of the Biophysical Setting. The name is matched to the BpS Code, not the BpS model number.
GROUPVEG: Coarse vegetation type groupings highlighting the high-level dominant vegetation within that BpS. Note that if a BpS is listed as ‚ÄòHardwood‚Äô it may actually be a mix of hardwood, herbaceous, savannah, and more, but LANDFIRE‚Äôs mapping identified hardwoods as dominating most of the landscape.
Fire Regime Attributes

FRI_REPLAC: Average historic replacement-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_MIXED: Average historic mixed-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_SURFAC: Average historic surface-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_ALLFIR: Average historic fire frequency for all fires within the BpS
PRC_REPLAC: Percent of historic fires with replacement severity for the BpS
PRC_MIXED: Percent of historic fires with mixed serverity for the BpS
PRC_SURFAC: Percent of historic fires with surface severity for the BpS
FRG_NEW: The fire regime group this BpS is found in. Fire regime groups are based on a combination of fire return interval and fire severity. The current Fire Regime Groups were updated in 2016, and have been modified from a previous classification. You can find the new breakdown of fire regime groups in the Attribute Data Dictionary for the BpS spatial data.

Fire Regime Groups are assigned as follows:

I-A (1A): Percent replacement fire less than 66.7%, fire return interval 0-5 years
I-B (1B): Percent replacement fire less than 66.7%, fire return interval 6-15 years
I-C (1C): Percent replacement fire less than 66.7%, fire return interval 16-35 years
II-A (2A): Percent replacement fire greater than 66.7%, fire return interval 0-5 years
II-B (2B): Percent replacement fire greater than 66.7%, fire return interval 6-15 years
II-C (2C): Percent replacement fire greater than 66.7%, fire return interval 16-35 years
III-A (3A): Percent replacement fire less than 80%, fire return interval 36-100 years
III-B (3B): Percent replacement fire less than 66.7%, fire return interval 101-200 years
IV-A (4A): Percent replacement fire greater than 80%, fire return interval 36-100 years
IV-B (4B): Percent replacement fire greater than 66.7%, fire return interval 101-200 years
V-A (5A): Any severity, fire return interval 201-500 years
V-B (5B): Any severity, fire return interval 501 or more years

title: Biophysical Settings Spatial Data
text:
Sometimes, people use LANDFIRE‚Äôs Environmental Site Potential (ESP) dataset when they should probably use BpS. We realized that there is a natural confusion here, as often people are looking for what they view as ‚Äúpotential vegetation‚Äù or ‚Äúvegetation that was once present at a site and hopefully could be again‚Äù. However, LANDFIRE created the Environmental Site Potential as a precursor to BpS data represent ‚Äúthe vegetation that could be supported at a given site based on the biophysical environment‚Äù (from https://landfire.gov/vegetation/esp).
While ESP is useful for some situations, the documentation for BpS is much more developed, and this concept is now thought of as artificial, as it represents conditions without disturbance, whereas the BpS data include natural disturbances.

title: LANDFIRE Datasets: An Overview
text:
LANDFIRE Vegetation Products: An Overview
In our work, we frequently utilize various vegetation and fire regime datasets to gain a deeper understanding of certain landscapes. Key datasets such as Biophysical Settings, Existing Vegetation, and Succession Class are integrated to create the Vegetation Departure (VDEP) product. This section of the website will give you an overview of these essential datasets, along with links to additional information and download options for your use.
Here, you‚Äôll learn how to access and make good use of these datasets. We‚Äôll walk you through how to download each one and share real-life examples of how they can be applied. We‚Äôll also introduce you to other helpful tools that can improve your work, making this a complete resource for everything LANDFIRE-related.


What you will learn in this section

A brief overview of some commonly used datasets
How to download and access LANDFIRE datasets
How these key LANDFIRE datasets are linked to one another

text:
LANDFIRE‚Äôs Biophysical Settings spatial product, also known as BpS, is a spatial representation of the BpS concept we discussed in the previous section. LANDFIRE uses BpS to depict reference conditions of vegetation across landscapes.
As of 2016, BpS now includes information on the historical fire regime, such as fire return intervals, percent of fire severities, and fire regime groups. Since LANDFIRE‚Äôs fire regime information is based on the historic context, we include it with BpS to provide a better picture of the pre-colonization landscape to the best of our knowledge.
The Biophysical Settings attributes correspond with the information in the Biophysical Settings Descriptions discussed in the BpS Descriptionsection of this website. We suggest that you review this information for a more complete understanding of the Biophysical Settings attributes.
For even more information, we‚Äôve created this short BpS 101 video on YouTube (3 minutes ).

title: Biophysical Settings Spatial Data
text:
BPS_CODE: The unique code LANDFIRE uses for each Biophysical Setting
Zone: The NLCD map zone(s) the Bps is located in or relates to
BPS_MODEL: The unique BpS Model code. This combines the BpS code with the zone(s) the model is located in. In some cases, a BpS with the same name and BpS Code may be split among map zones because the vegetation or disturbance regimes vary enough that the descriptions differ. An example of this is the ‚ÄòLaurentian-Acadian Northern Hardwoods forest‚Äô BpS (13020), which has four different BpS Models, although it is mapped as one BpS type.
BPS_NAME: The name of the Biophysical Setting. The name is matched to the BpS Code, not the BpS model number.
GROUPVEG: Coarse vegetation type groupings highlighting the high-level dominant vegetation within that BpS. Note that if a BpS is listed as ‚ÄòHardwood‚Äô it may actually be a mix of hardwood, herbaceous, savannah, and more, but LANDFIRE‚Äôs mapping identified hardwoods as dominating most of the landscape.
Fire Regime Attributes

FRI_REPLAC: Average historic replacement-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_MIXED: Average historic mixed-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_SURFAC: Average historic surface-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_ALLFIR: Average historic fire frequency for all fires within the BpS.
PRC_REPLAC: Percent of historic fires with replacement severity for the BpS
PRC_MIXED: Percent of historic fires with mixed serverity for the BpS
PRC_SURFAC: Percent of historic fires with surface severity for the BpS
FRG_NEW: The fire regime group this BpS is found in. Fire regime groups are based on a combination of fire return interval and fire severity. The current Fire Regime Groups were updated in 2016, and have been modified from a previous classification. You can find the new breakdown of fire regime groups in the Attribute Data Dictionaryfor the BpS spatial data.

title: Explore LANDFIRE spatial data
text:
Exploring the attributes of any dataset is a fundamental step in the data analysis process. It lays the foundation for accurate analyses, informed decision-making, and successful outcomes in various fields, from scientific research to business intelligence.
Here are three main reasons to understand the attributes of LANDFIRE data before any analysis in GIS or R:

Data Familiarity: Exploring attributes provides a deep understanding of the dataset‚Äôs structure, format, and content. This familiarity is essential for making informed decisions about data manipulation, analysis, and visualization.
Understanding Data Quality: Examining data attributes helps assess the quality and reliability of the dataset. Identifying missing or inaccurate information early on can prevent errors in analyses and decision-making processes.
Effective Data Visualization: Exploring attributes aids in creating effective data visualizations. Understanding the range and distribution of variables helps you choose appropriate visualization techniques that convey the intended message and insights.

üí° Screenshots of where to find the datasets and attributes are below for those who find them useful.
Whenever you download a LANDFIRE dataset, it will be packaged in a .zip file that includes not only the spatial data in .tif format, but also general metadata, spatial metadata, and a .csv data file. .csv stands for ‚ÄòComma Separated Values‚Äô and is a convenient way to display and work with the attributes of a spatial data layer in a non-spatial way (R, Excel, etc.). This enables you to examine your data and understand landscape trends without even opening GIS software. It also helps you understand the attributes you may want to map and explore spatially.

Exploring the .csv files of a LANDFIRE spatial layer

Within the dataset folder or zip file, you should have a folder titled ‚ÄòCSV_Data‚Äô. Click on this folder to access the .csv file.
Double click on the Microsoft Excel Comma Separated Values File to open it in Microsoft Excel.

If you don‚Äôt use Microsoft Excel or you aren‚Äôt working in a Microsoft Windows environment, this file may not default to opening in Excel. In that case, right click, navigate to ‚Äòopen with‚Äô, and choose the spreadsheet program of your choice to view the file.

Here you can explore the attributes and values of the datasets. We recommend using the metadata and/or data dictionary as a guide to better understand what each of the field names means and what data are being reported under that field.

title: Biophysical Settings: An Overview
text:
Potential Natural Vegetation
This concept might be best described by Hengl et al., (2018), ‚ÄúPotential natural vegetation (PNV) is the vegetation cover in equilibrium with climate, that would exist at a given location if not impacted by human activities‚Äù. The BpS concept differs from PNV in a couple key ways:

The BpS concept includes both natural disturbances and indigenous management activities such as the use of fire, which was extensive in some areas prior to European colonization.
PNVs are typically ‚Äòstatic‚Äô, meaning they represent one ‚Äústate‚Äù which is often the ‚Äòclimax‚Äô state. BpSs almost always include multiple ‚Äústates‚Äù representing a dynamic system.

title: Biophysical Settings: An Overview
text:
Pre-colonization vegetation
These datasets rely on historical accounts, early land surveys and other methods such as sediment analysis to map ecosystems at a certain point in time. For example, land survey driven ecosystem maps often represent conditions as of ~ 1830s. The BpSs differ in that they:

do not represent a specific point in time, rather the pre-European condition generally
are systems with multiple classes, just like PNVs.

As you will learn in the following sections, LANDFIRE maps, describes, and models each BpS.

title: The Reference Conditions Table
text:
What you will learn here
The Reference Conditions Table (RCT) is essentially an output from the Biophysical Settings Models that focuses specifically on succession class and fire regime. In this section we will:

Explore the fields in the RCT
Discuss RCT use cases
Explain where to get the table



The Reference Conditions Table






Note



üí° We suggest you review the content on Biophysical Settings, specifically the Biophysical Settings Spatial Data page where we discuss BpS attributes, before you work through this material. We discuss Succession Class in more detail in a later section of this website.


The RCT as downloaded is a .csv file with the following fields:

Biophysical Settings identifiers:

BpS_Code
BpS_Name
Model_Code

Succession Class Reference Percents, Classes A ‚Äì E, e.g., ‚ÄòClassA_ReferencePercent‚Äô
Fire Return Intervals, e.g., ‚ÄòFRI_ReplacementFire‚Äô
Percent of fires, surface, mixed and replacement, e.g., ‚ÄòPercentOfFires_ReplacementFire‚Äô
Fire Regime Group: FRG_New



Some common uses of the Reference Conditions Table
This table can be a quick way to get reference percentages and to understand overall historical fire dynamics of BpSs. We use the RCT to:

Get reference succession class percentages when making charts such as the demo figure inserted below. This figure depicts reference vs.¬†current succession classes for the Southern Rockies ecoregion and could be helpful when thinking about the major Biophysical Settings on a landscape and how their succession classes may (or may not) have changed over time.
Understand the relative proportion of surface, mixed, and replacement fire severity for a given Biophysical Setting.
Compare fire frequency, severity, and fire regime between Biophysical Settings.




Reference vs.¬†current succession classes for the Southern Rockies ecoregion.



Quickly calculate estimated historical annual acres burned.

-   **Quantify the amount of a BpS on the landscape**: Let ( A ) represent the acres of the landscape. For example, ( A = 200,000 ) acres.

-   **Quantify the return interval:** Let ( R ) be the return interval. For this example, ( R = 25 ), so the annual probability ( P ) is given by: P = 1/R = 1/25 = 0.04

-   **Calculate the Area Affected by Surface Fire**: You multiply the acres on the landscape by the return interval. The area affected ( S ) can be calculated as:

    S=A√óP

-   Putting it all together, the equation becomes:

    S=200,000√ó(0.04)=8,000 acres of surface fire

The following chart depicts annual acres burned, all fire types, for the most dominant BpSs of the Southern Rockies.

![Annual acres burned for all fire types in the Southern Rockies biophysical settings.](images/RCT_AcresBurned.png)
The reference conditions table is important in landscape assessments and LANDFIRE‚Äôs vegetation departure, both of which we will discuss more in-depth in future sections of this learning website.


Where to find the Reference Conditions Table
The RCT is downloadable on the Bps Models page of the LANDFIRE Program website. Scroll down to the ‚ÄúDownload BpS Models and Descriptions‚Äù section, then click ‚ÄúReference Conditions‚Äù which will begin an immediate download. Unless you specify the download location, the file will likely end up in your default Downloads folder.
To access the file, open the .csv in Excel, R, or any other program you use to view .csv files.



Where to download the Reference Conditions Table

title: What is LANDFIRE
text:
LANDFIRE, Landscape Fire and Resource Management Planning Tools, is a shared program between the wildland fire management programs of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service Fire and Aviation branch, and the U.S. Department of the Interior, that provides more than twenty landscape-scale geo-spatial products, 950 vegetation models, and a suite of tools that support all-lands planning, management, and operations. Learn more about the dynamic LANDFIRE Program.


LANDFIRE‚Äôs mission is to provide agency leaders and managers with a common ‚Äúall-lands‚Äù data set of vegetation and wildland fire/fuels information for strategic fire and resource management planning and analysis.



The LANDFIRE Program delivers current, consistent, comprehensive data for the entire United States, including Alaska, Hawai‚Äôi, and Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands.
This multi-partner program produces current, consistent, comprehensive, geospatial data and databases that describe vegetation, wildland fuel, and fire regimes across the United States and insular areas. Use the LANDFIRE Technical Documentation to learn how LF creates the data. Use the LANDFIRE Data Dictionary to help understand and locate LANDFIRE information.
LF products are available by the following groupings:

Reference - contribute data or access databases containing contributed disturbance events
Disturbance - a suite of products that categorizes annual and historical disturbance events
Vegetation - products that demonstrate vegetation change across the landscape and models of potential pre-European settlement vegetation systems
Fuel - products that demonstrate the composition and characteristics of surface and canopy fuels along with fuel vegetation
Historical Fire Regime - products that represent pre-European settlement fire frequency and severity
Topographic - products that provide geospatial information describing the landscape

title: What is LANDFIRE
section: What is The Nature Conservancy‚Äôs connection?
text:
What is The Nature Conservancy‚Äôs connection?
The Nature Conservancy (TNC) is a major partner in the LANDFIRE Program supported by a cooperative agreement through the USDA Forest Service. TNC‚Äôs LANDFIRE Team works closely with the LANDFIRE Business Leads, program staff, and other partners to provide support to LANDFIRE users.
LANDFIRE user support can take many forms. Providing this assistance can range from in-person and online workshops to monthly office hours, newsletters and data alerts to learning website development and technical, personalized assistance. TNC‚Äôs LANDFIRE team is dedicated to developing current, user-focused LANDFIRE resources that advance natural resource work, amplify the appropriate use of LANDFIRE products, and leverage the collective knowledge of the natural resource community.
LANDFIRE‚Äôs website offers a wealth of resources related to wildland fire and natural resource management. Users can access all LANDFIRE data, resources, applications, and update information on the LANDFIRE Program website.

title: Biophysical Settings Models
text:
On this page you will find guidance on:

The basics of Biophysical Settings models
Downloading and installing SyncroSim, the software we use for LANDFIRE‚Äôs models
Loading all LANDFIRE BpS models using the LANDFIRE Package
Isolating a subset of BpS models
Exploring the models you are interested in







Note



Note, there are many resources for these steps on the internet, so this page will cover the highlights, and point to those resources at the bottom.

title: Biophysical Settings Models
text:
Download and Install SyncroSim
Installing SyncroSim is similar to installing most software, i.e., you download the application, then click to start an installer, etc. You can find the software on the SyncroSim website - we typically accept all defaults when installing.
Installing on a governmental machine may present challenges, but approval and updates are in the works.
Running SyncroSim on a Mac is generally not recommended. For more information on this, see the getting started documentation on the SyncroSim website.

title: Biophysical Settings Models
section: Load all LANDFIRE BpS models using the LANDFIRE Package
text:
Load all LANDFIRE BpS models using the LANDFIRE Package






Note: Screenshots of the process are included below the written instructions for those who find them useful.



While SyncroSim is powerful as downloaded, adding ‚Äòpackages‚Äô will bring even more functionality. For our work you will need to add in the ST-Sim and landfirevegmodels packages. In SyncroSim:

Go to File -> Packages. Click the ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù button.
From the list check the ‚ÄúSt-Sim‚Äù and ‚Äúlandfirevegmodels‚Äù packages, when click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù. The install will happen automatically.
Close the ‚ÄúPackages‚Äù window.
Once you have those packages installed, you are ready to bring in the LANDFIRE vegetation models. To do that will take a few steps:

Note: you will need internet for this section.

Go to File -> New‚Ä¶ This will bring up a ‚ÄúNew Library‚Äù window.
In the New Library window highlight ‚Äúlandfirevegmodels‚Äù at the top of the window, then select ‚ÄúReference Models‚Äù near the bottom.
Note where the ‚ÄúReference Models‚Äù library will be saved. Change the location if needed. Hit ‚ÄúOK‚Äù, then grab a beverage or go for a walk as this will take a few minutes.







Note: an ‚ÄúUpdate Library‚Äù window may open once the Reference Models library is downloaded. Click ‚ÄúApply‚Äù at the bottom of that window to proceed.



Once you complete these steps, SyncroSim will have downloaded and loaded the LANDFIRE BpS Reference Condition Models library into your ‚ÄúLibrary Explorer‚Äù window.

Screenshots of loading LANDFIRE Package and Reference Conditions Library



Packages Pane





Select packages

title: Biophysical Settings Models
section: Isolate a subset of BpS model
text:
Isolate a subset of BpS model
You can access a set of downloadable instructions (pdf) and much more information on Biophysical Settings models on the LANDFIRE Vegetation Modeling website.






Note



Screenshots of the process are included below the written instructions for those who find them useful.


We assume you will not want to explore all 900+ LANDFIRE models, so we outline how to subset one or more individual models below.

For good luck close and re-open SyncroSim. Seriously, after installing packages and libraries some of the functions just work better if you do so.
If it is not there, open the LANDFIRE BpS Reference Condition Models library by going to File -> Open then navigating to the ‚ÄúReference-Condition-Models.ssim‚Äù file, likely in your SyncroSim directory. You will then click ‚ÄúOpen‚Äù.
Once opened, the LANDFIRE BpS Reference Condition Models will be in the Library Explorer pane. You will also see, within the library, a ‚Äúproject‚Äù named ‚ÄúDefinitions‚Äù and a ‚ÄúScenaro‚Äù named ‚ÄúReference Condition Models‚Äù.
Click the ‚ÄúReference Condition Models‚Äù scenario once to highlight it.
Go to Edit -> Export LFVM Strata to bring up the selection window.
Once at the Export LFVM Strata window, you will check the BpSs of interest, give a file name for the new library and assign a folder that it will be saved to.







Note



Note: we do not suggest selecting many strata at once until you are familiar with the modeling process. Stick to 1-3 initially.



Screenshots of Isolating a model



Select scenario





Export strata





Create a new library with selected strata

title: Biophysical Settings Models
section: Explore the models you are interested in
text:
Explore the models you are interested in






Note



Note: Screenshots of the process are included below the written instructions for those who find them useful.


OK you are doing a great job. Now you have a library with a subset of strata (i.e., BpSs in this case) that you care about. Now what?
By exploring the BpS models you can learn how the modeling experts parameterized them, and more interactively see how the disturbances and states all fit together.
Start exploring:

Double click on ‚ÄúReference Condition Models‚Äù then the Transition Pathways tab.
To make viewing easier go to Window -> Arrange All.
At the bottom will be tabs of all of the BpSs that are in this library. Click any one. See ‚ÄúTransitions Pane‚Äù.
Click on any box to see the pathways associated with that state (i.e., succession class).
If you want to run the scenario:

Go to ‚ÄúOutput Options‚Äù tab within the scenario, make sure that the ‚ÄúState classes every‚Äù box is set to 100 (i.e., not ‚Äú1‚Äù).
Go to ‚ÄúRun Control tab‚Äù and set the ‚ÄòTotal iterations‚Äô to 2.
In the ‚ÄúInitial Conditions‚Äù tab, insure that the ‚ÄúTotal Acres‚Äùand ‚ÄúNumber of Simulation cells‚Äù boxes both have ‚Äú1,000‚Äù For exploring we recommend these three steps as it will speed up your runs.
In the Library Explorer highlight the scenario, then click the small green triangle at the top of the screen.

Make a chart by clicking the ‚ÄúNew‚Äù icon in the ‚ÄúCharts‚Äù pane, then name it appropriately. You will change some settings to get your first chart:

Change Line Chart to Column Chart (top left of window)
Under ‚ÄúState Classes‚Äù select ‚ÄúProportion‚Äù
Under ‚ÄúDisaggregate by‚Äù check the ‚ÄúState Class‚Äù box
Under ‚ÄúInclude Data For‚Äù, click ‚ÄúState Class‚Äù then select the appropriate state classes
Note: if you have multiple BpSs, you will also want to go to and select one ‚ÄúModel‚Äù under the ‚ÄúInclude Data For‚Äù dropdown
Click ‚ÄúApply‚Äù

title: LANDFIRE Datasets: An Overview
text:
LANDFIRE Vegetation Products: An Overview
In our work, we frequently utilize various vegetation and fire regime datasets to gain a deeper understanding of certain landscapes. Key datasets such as Biophysical Settings, Existing Vegetation, and Succession Class are integrated to create the Vegetation Departure (VDEP) product. This section of the website will give you an overview of these essential datasets, along with links to additional information and download options for your use.
Here, you‚Äôll learn how to access and make good use of these datasets. We‚Äôll walk you through how to download each one and share real-life examples of how they can be applied. We‚Äôll also introduce you to other helpful tools that can improve your work, making this a complete resource for everything LANDFIRE-related.


What you will learn in this section

A brief overview of some commonly used datasets
How to download and access LANDFIRE datasets
How these key LANDFIRE datasets are linked to one another

title: The Reference Conditions Table
text:
What you will learn here
The Reference Conditions Table (RCT) is essentially an output from the Biophysical Settings Models that focuses specifically on succession class and fire regime. In this section we will:

Explore the fields in the RCT
Discuss RCT use cases
Explain where to get the table



The Reference Conditions Table






Note



üí° We suggest you review the content on Biophysical Settings, specifically the Biophysical Settings Spatial Data page where we discuss BpS attributes, before you work through this material. We discuss Succession Class in more detail in a later section of this website.


The RCT as downloaded is a .csv file with the following fields:

Biophysical Settings identifiers:

BpS_Code
BpS_Name
Model_Code

Succession Class Reference Percents, Classes A ‚Äì E, e.g., ‚ÄòClassA_ReferencePercent‚Äô
Fire Return Intervals, e.g., ‚ÄòFRI_ReplacementFire‚Äô
Percent of fires, surface, mixed and replacement, e.g., ‚ÄòPercentOfFires_ReplacementFire‚Äô
Fire Regime Group: FRG_New



Some common uses of the Reference Conditions Table
This table can be a quick way to get reference percentages and to understand overall historical fire dynamics of BpSs. We use the RCT to:

Get reference succession class percentages when making charts such as the demo figure inserted below. This figure depicts reference vs.¬†current succession classes for the Southern Rockies ecoregion and could be helpful when thinking about the major Biophysical Settings on a landscape and how their succession classes may (or may not) have changed over time.
Understand the relative proportion of surface, mixed, and replacement fire severity for a given Biophysical Setting.
Compare fire frequency, severity, and fire regime between Biophysical Settings.




Reference vs.¬†current succession classes for the Southern Rockies ecoregion.



Quickly calculate estimated historical annual acres burned.
Quantify the amount of a BpS on the landscape: Let ( A ) represent the acres of the landscape. For example, ( A = 200,000 ) acres.
Quantify the return interval: Let ( R ) be the return interval. For this example, ( R = 25 ), so the annual probability ( P ) is given by: P = 1/R = 1/25 = 0.04
Calculate the Area Affected by Surface Fire: You multiply the acres on the landscape by the return interval. The area affected ( S ) can be calculated as:
S=A√óP
Putting it all together, the equation becomes:
S=200,000√ó(0.04)=8,000 acres of surface fire
The following chart depicts annual acres burned, all fire types, for the most dominant BpSs of the Southern Rockies.




Annual acres burned for all fire types in the Southern Rockies biophysical settings.


The reference conditions table is important in landscape assessments and LANDFIRE‚Äôs vegetation departure, both of which we will discuss more in-depth in future sections of this learning website.


Where to find the Reference Conditions Table
The RCT is downloadable on the Bps Models page of the LANDFIRE Program website. Scroll down to the ‚ÄúDownload BpS Models and Descriptions‚Äù section, then click ‚ÄúReference Conditions‚Äù which will begin an immediate download. Unless you specify the download location, the file will likely end up in your default Downloads folder.
To access the file, open the .csv in Excel, R, or any other program you use to view .csv files.



Where to download the Reference Conditions Table

Most text terms will work, numbers will not. For example, ‚Äòhurricane‚Äô will return BpSs, ‚Äò1362‚Äô (an actual BpS number) will not.

Download documents of interest

Warning



‚ö†Ô∏è Beware when clicking the ‚ÄòDownload All Search Results Documents‚Äô button. If not careful you will end up with a huge download of many more documents than you want! Make sure to filter by ‚ÄòVegetation Types‚Äô and/or ‚ÄòMap Zones‚Äô first.

title: Biophysical Settings Descriptions
section: File name, Map Zones and that number at the top
text:
File name, Map Zones and that number at the top
The BpS documents were saved with a numeric code such as ‚Äú13700_60_63_64_65_66.docx‚Äù. This number represents three things:

BpS code: this is the first 4 digits, e.g., ‚Äú1370‚Äù in our example for the ‚ÄúAppalachian (Hemlock-)Northern Hardwood Forest‚Äù.
BpS splits: this is the fifth digit, or ‚Äú0‚Äù in our example. Occasionally an original BpS would be ‚Äòsplit‚Äô into multiple. For example, in the Great Lakes there is a ‚ÄúBoreal White Spruce-Fir-Hardwood Forest - Inland‚Äù (BpS code 13651), and a ‚ÄúBoreal White Spruce-Fir-Hardwood Forest - Coastal‚Äù (BpS code 13652), which have a ‚Äú1‚Äù and a ‚Äú2‚Äù in the file name, and BpS code.
Map Zones: the string of numbers separated by an underscore represents the Map Zones that this particular document (and associated BpS state and transition model) apply to.







üí° Why are Map Zones important?
Map zones in LANDFIRE are created through a collaborative effort involving multiple organizations including USGS, US DOI, USDA Forest Service and TNC. Map zones are important for LANDFIRE because they divide the landscape into manageable sections, ensuring consistent data collection and analysis including modeling vegetation and fire and fuels behavior. Each map zone represents distinct ecological regions, helping to depict reference conditions and natural plant communities that existed historically.

title: Biophysical Settings Descriptions
text:
Fire Frequency Table
The Fire Frequency Table can be confusing. A few things to keep in mind when viewing this table include:

The Severity, Avg FI (FI - Fire Interval), and Percent of All Fires values are imported from the Syncro Sim model
The values in the Avg FI and Percent of All Fires columns are essentially a ‚Äòcomposite‚Äô across all succession classes, which may include classes which have very short FIs, and classes with very long FIs.
The Min FI and Max FI columns are user populated, and may not necessarily correspond to the Avg FI and Percent of All Fires columns.

An example Fire Frequency table is replicated below.

Fire interval is expressed in years for each fire severity class and for all types of fire combined (All Fires). Average FI is the central tendency modeled. Percent of all fires is the percent of fires modeled in that severity class. Minimum and Maximum FIs show the relative range of fire intervals as estimated by model contributors, if known.

text:
Succession Classes Table
LANDFIRE did not attempt to map where succession classes were prior to European colonization, as they would have moved around. This table is used to map where succession classes are today. For example, in the ‚ÄòSuccession Class Table‚Äô below we have highlighted combinations of Existing Height and Cover (and lifeform) that would be mapped as Succession Class A.

title: Biophysical Settings: An Overview
text:
Biophysical Settings are a foundational concept for LANDFIRE defined on the LANDFIRE Program website as:

‚Äú‚Ä¶a modeled representation of the vegetation system that may have been dominant on the landscape prior to Euro-American settlement and is based on both the current biophysical environment and an approximation of modeled past disturbance regimes.‚Äù

We like to think of the BpSs as ‚Äúecosystem habitats‚Äù, or ‚Äúpotential ecosystem footprints‚Äù. The BpS concept asks ‚Äúwhere might an ecosystem occur‚Äù based on abiotic factors such as soils, surficial geology, slope and elevation as well as natural disturbance regimes.

title: Biophysical Settings: An Overview
text:
Potential Natural Vegetation
This concept might be best described by Hengl et al., (2018), ‚ÄúPotential natural vegetation (PNV) is the vegetation cover in equilibrium with climate, that would exist at a given location if not impacted by human activities‚Äù. The BpS concept differs from PNV in a couple key ways:

The BpS concept includes both natural disturbances and indigenous management activities such as the use of fire, which was extensive in some areas prior to European colonization.
PNVs are typically ‚Äòstatic‚Äô, meaning they represent one ‚Äústate‚Äù which is often the ‚Äòclimax‚Äô state. BpSs almost always include multiple ‚Äústates‚Äù representing a dynamic system.

title: Biophysical Settings: An Overview
text:
Pre-colonization vegetation
These datasets rely on historical accounts, early land surveys and other methods such as sediment analysis to map ecosystems at a certain point in time. For example, land survey driven ecosystem maps often represent conditions as of ~ 1830s. The BpSs differ in that they:

do not represent a specific point in time, rather the pre-European condition generally
are systems with multiple classes, just like PNVs.

As you will learn in the following sections, LANDFIRE maps, describes, and models each BpS.

title: Biophysical Settings Spatial Data
text:
An overview of the Biophysical Settings spatial data
Key attributes of the Biophysical Settings spatial data
Where to find Biophysical Settings data on the LANDFIRE Program website
Common mistakes with Biophysical Settings data (and how to avoid them)









LANDFIRE delivers Biophysical Settings data and models for the entire United States, including Alaska and Hawaii. Puerto Rico and the US Virgin Islands do not have BpS data developed. 950 Biophysical Settings are grouped into seven major vegetation classes and displayed using one color family for each class.





LANDFIRE‚Äôs Biophysical Settings spatial product, also known as BpS, is a spatial representation of the BpS concept we discussed in the previous section. LANDFIRE uses BpS to depict reference conditions of vegetation across landscapes.
As of 2016, BpS now includes information on the historical fire regime, such as fire return intervals, percent of fire severities, and fire regime groups. Since LANDFIRE‚Äôs fire regime information is based on the historic context, we include it with BpS to provide a better picture of the pre-colonization landscape to the best of our knowledge.
The Biophysical Settings attributes correspond with the information in the Biophysical Settings Descriptions discussed in the BpS Descriptionsection of this website. We suggest that you review this information for a more complete understanding of the Biophysical Settings attributes.
For even more information, we‚Äôve created this short BpS 101 video on YouTube (3 minutes ).




BPS_CODE: The unique code LANDFIRE uses for each Biophysical Setting
Zone: The NLCD map zone(s) the Bps is located in or relates to
BPS_MODEL: The unique BpS Model code. This combines the BpS code with the zone(s) the model is located in. In some cases, a BpS with the same name and BpS Code may be split among map zones because the vegetation or disturbance regimes vary enough that the descriptions differ. An example of this is the ‚ÄòLaurentian-Acadian Northern Hardwoods forest‚Äô BpS (13020), which has four different BpS Models, although it is mapped as one BpS type.
BPS_NAME: The name of the Biophysical Setting. The name is matched to the BpS Code, not the BpS model number.
GROUPVEG: Coarse vegetation type groupings highlighting the high-level dominant vegetation within that BpS. Note that if a BpS is listed as ‚ÄòHardwood‚Äô it may actually be a mix of hardwood, herbaceous, savannah, and more, but LANDFIRE‚Äôs mapping identified hardwoods as dominating most of the landscape.
Fire Regime Attributes

FRI_REPLAC: Average historic replacement-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_MIXED: Average historic mixed-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_SURFAC: Average historic surface-severity fire frequency for the BpS
FRI_ALLFIR: Average historic fire frequency for all fires within the BpS.
PRC_REPLAC: Percent of historic fires with replacement severity for the BpS
PRC_MIXED: Percent of historic fires with mixed serverity for the BpS
PRC_SURFAC: Percent of historic fires with surface severity for the BpS
FRG_NEW: The fire regime group this BpS is found in. Fire regime groups are based on a combination of fire return interval and fire severity. The current Fire Regime Groups were updated in 2016, and have been modified from a previous classification. You can find the new breakdown of fire regime groups in the Attribute Data Dictionaryfor the BpS spatial data.





The Biophysical Settings data is included in the Vegetation section of the LANDFIRE Program Website on the Biophysical Settings page. Here you will find an overview, including the information above along with further details and links to other important documents. Perhaps of most interest are the download links - via the LANDFIRE Map Viewer, full extent downloads, and a variety of ways to stream data into your maps. The page also includes resources such as attribute tables, metadata, and supplemental information.



Screenshot of Data Access and Resources on the Biophysical Settings data page






Bps Attribute Data Dictionary
LANDFIRE Helpdesk

title: Biophysical Settings Models
text:
On this page you will find guidance on:

The basics of Biophysical Settings models
Downloading and installing SyncroSim, the software we use for LANDFIRE‚Äôs models
Loading all LANDFIRE BpS models using the LANDFIRE Package
Isolating a subset of BpS models
Exploring the models you are interested in







Note



Note, there are many resources for these steps on the internet, so this page will cover the highlights, and point to those resources at the bottom.

title: Biophysical Settings Models
text:
Download and Install SyncroSim
Installing SyncroSim is similar to installing most software, i.e., you download the application, then click to start an installer, etc. You can find the software on the SyncroSim website - we typically accept all defaults when installing.
Installing on a governmental machine may present challenges, but approval and updates are in the works.
Running SyncroSim on a Mac is generally not recommended. For more information on this, see the getting started documentation on the SyncroSim website.

title: Biophysical Settings Models
section: Load all LANDFIRE BpS models using the LANDFIRE Package
text:
Load all LANDFIRE BpS models using the LANDFIRE Package






Note: Screenshots of the process are included below the written instructions for those who find them useful.



While SyncroSim is powerful as downloaded, adding ‚Äòpackages‚Äô will bring even more functionality. For our work you will need to add in the ST-Sim and landfirevegmodels packages. In SyncroSim:

Go to File -> Packages. Click the ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù button.
From the list check the ‚ÄúSt-Sim‚Äù and ‚Äúlandfirevegmodels‚Äù packages, when click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù. The install will happen automatically.
Close the ‚ÄúPackages‚Äù window.
Once you have those packages installed, you are ready to bring in the LANDFIRE vegetation models. To do that will take a few steps:

Note: you will need internet for this section.

Go to File -> New‚Ä¶ This will bring up a ‚ÄúNew Library‚Äù window.
In the New Library window highlight ‚Äúlandfirevegmodels‚Äù at the top of the window, then select ‚ÄúReference Models‚Äù near the bottom.
Note where the ‚ÄúReference Models‚Äù library will be saved. Change the location if needed. Hit ‚ÄúOK‚Äù, then grab a beverage or go for a walk as this will take a few minutes.







Note: an ‚ÄúUpdate Library‚Äù window may open once the Reference Models library is downloaded. Click ‚ÄúApply‚Äù at the bottom of that window to proceed.



Once you complete these steps, SyncroSim will have downloaded and loaded the LANDFIRE BpS Reference Condition Models library into your ‚ÄúLibrary Explorer‚Äù window.

Screenshots of loading LANDFIRE Package and Reference Conditions Library



Packages Pane





Select packages

title: Biophysical Settings Models
section: Isolate a subset of BpS model
text:
Isolate a subset of BpS model
You can access a set of downloadable instructions (pdf) and much more information on Biophysical Settings models on the LANDFIRE Vegetation Modeling website.






Note



Screenshots of the process are included below the written instructions for those who find them useful.


We assume you will not want to explore all 900+ LANDFIRE models, so we outline how to subset one or more individual models below.

For good luck close and re-open SyncroSim. Seriously, after installing packages and libraries some of the functions just work better if you do so.
If it is not there, open the LANDFIRE BpS Reference Condition Models library by going to File -> Open then navigating to the ‚ÄúReference-Condition-Models.ssim‚Äù file, likely in your SyncroSim directory. You will then click ‚ÄúOpen‚Äù.
Once opened, the LANDFIRE BpS Reference Condition Models will be in the Library Explorer pane. You will also see, within the library, a ‚Äúproject‚Äù named ‚ÄúDefinitions‚Äù and a ‚ÄúScenaro‚Äù named ‚ÄúReference Condition Models‚Äù.
Click the ‚ÄúReference Condition Models‚Äù scenario once to highlight it.
Go to Edit -> Export LFVM Strata to bring up the selection window.
Once at the Export LFVM Strata window, you will check the BpSs of interest, give a file name for the new library and assign a folder that it will be saved to.







Note



Note: we do not suggest selecting many strata at once until you are familiar with the modeling process. Stick to 1-3 initially.

title: Biophysical Settings Models
section: Explore the models you are interested in
text:
Explore the models you are interested in






Note



Note: Screenshots of the process are included below the written instructions for those who find them useful.


OK you are doing a great job. Now you have a library with a subset of strata (i.e., BpSs in this case) that you care about. Now what?
By exploring the BpS models you can learn how the modeling experts parameterized them, and more interactively see how the disturbances and states all fit together.
Start exploring:

Double click on ‚ÄúReference Condition Models‚Äù then the Transition Pathways tab.
To make viewing easier go to Window -> Arrange All.
At the bottom will be tabs of all of the BpSs that are in this library. Click any one. See ‚ÄúTransitions Pane‚Äù.
Click on any box to see the pathways associated with that state (i.e., succession class).
If you want to run the scenario:

Go to ‚ÄúOutput Options‚Äù tab within the scenario, make sure that the ‚ÄúState classes every‚Äù box is set to 100 (i.e., not ‚Äú1‚Äù).
Go to ‚ÄúRun Control tab‚Äù and set the ‚ÄòTotal iterations‚Äô to 2.
In the ‚ÄúInitial Conditions‚Äù tab, insure that the ‚ÄúTotal Acres‚Äùand ‚ÄúNumber of Simulation cells‚Äù boxes both have ‚Äú1,000‚Äù For exploring we recommend these three steps as it will speed up your runs.
In the Library Explorer highlight the scenario, then click the small green triangle at the top of the screen.

Make a chart by clicking the ‚ÄúNew‚Äù icon in the ‚ÄúCharts‚Äù pane, then name it appropriately. You will change some settings to get your first chart:

Change Line Chart to Column Chart (top left of window)
Under ‚ÄúState Classes‚Äù select ‚ÄúProportion‚Äù
Under ‚ÄúDisaggregate by‚Äù check the ‚ÄúState Class‚Äù box
Under ‚ÄúInclude Data For‚Äù, click ‚ÄúState Class‚Äù then select the appropriate state classes
Note: if you have multiple BpSs, you will also want to go to and select one ‚ÄúModel‚Äù under the ‚ÄúInclude Data For‚Äù dropdown
Click ‚ÄúApply‚Äù
